page.title: 02Malvern Hills & Commons
page.content: The whole of this area was once part of the Royal Forest of Malvern Chase. This was sold to raise money for the monarchy in the 17th century, and large areas were left as common land. Public concern over the enclosing of the commons brought about the{Malvern Hills Act 1884.}The Act set up a{Board of Conservators,}unpaid and elected, to safeguard the rights of the commoners and to give the public right of access for recreation. An income is given from the rates. In order to stop the{quarrying}on the Hills the Conservators were given some limited powers of compulsory purchase in 1924 and quarrying finally ended in 1977. The last quarry to be worked was the Gullet at Midsummmer Hill. The National Trust own Midsummer Hill and Broad Down.
